an overview of aws and amazon redshift and then we'll hear from our partners
dices
on big data challenges and opportunities as well as customer use case
and how to maximize your business impact with big data and amazon redshift so without further delay
i'd like to please welcome our guest today amar abbas who's the vice president of

dices and we have matt yanchen who is our ecosystem solution architect here at
amazon web services so with that take it away matt thanks sherry
so before we get started and actually talk about redshift i just wanted to speak briefly about the amazon web
services platform amazon web services is a scalable secure and cost-effective platform for running
your cloud computing workloads this is a simple view of the set of services that we offer the
compute storage and data services are at the heart of the offering we then surround these services with a
range of supporting components like management tools networking services and application augmentation services all
this is hosted within our global data center footprint that allows you to consume services without having to build out facilities or equipment
there's a lot of equipment powering these cloud services in fact every day aws adds enough server capacity to power
amazon.com in 2003 when it was a 5 billion enterprise
database services is a foundation service of aws database service customers are offered a
broad choice for their database platform enabling them to deploy the best data store for their use case
all database services are fully managed which means they provide automated management of low-level administrative functions
this enables developers and administrators to focus on application functionality and performance rather than on patching and backup
maintenance elasticash provides a managed memcache memcache d service for accelerating
frequently read data by caching in a memory rds is the relational database service rds provides a choice of database
engines mysql oracle and sql server in a high performance durable configuration that can be provisioned in
minutes multi-az replication is a feature of this service designed for production instances multi-az provides one-click dr
to a remote data center for fast failover and maximum data protection dynamodb is the default choice for new
application development dynamodb is a nosql datastore designed for fast predictable performance at any scale
a feature of dynamodb is the ability to dial up and down provision throughput in order to meet changes in the workload
finally we get to reshift redshift is where we will be spending this session it's a data warehouse that has been specifically enhanced for the cloud
and was developed after many customers requested a fully managed high skill option for analytical workloads
so redshift was conceived with a simple set of objectives to be faster cheaper and easier to use than any other
data warehouse alternative to achieve these goals every aspect of the service has been optimized for data warehouse workloads with extensive use
of automation io efficiency and with extensive use of automation i o efficiency is especially important
for performance and eliminating unnecessary i o has been one of the great focuses of the redshift team
here's some common customer use cases that we've seen so far rent shift is a relatively young service having launched in early 2013 but already we're seeing
widespread adoption in a variety of use cases first and foremost customers are able to reduce their costs by extending
the data warehouse rather than adding hardware to their additional warehouse they're migrating away from their data warehouse systems in some cases
completely and they're able to really respond faster it all comes down to agility cost and ability to grow your capacity
with little or no risk you can scale data warehouse capacity as demand grows or scale it back as you don't need it you can reduce
hardware and software costs dramatically by an order of magnitude and we'll talk about this more in a bit importantly your performance
can be improved by an order of magnitude as well by migrating to redshift and you can make data more data available for analysis
here's an example of some customers who are already publicly using redshift airbnb has been quite vocal about both our hadoop
managed to do platform emr and also redshift airbnb has seen a 5 to 20 reduction in
query times and a four times cost reduction over hive on hadoop that they were using previously
according media has seen similar reductions in fact even greater reductions in query times and an enterprise customer nokia has
seen a 50 reduction in costs and also a notable improvement in query time so again you're seeing both cost reductions and actual improved
performance when you switch to redshift so what is redshift under the hood it's
there's several ways in which we reduce i o in redshift first of all this storage is directly attached to the redshift
servers and large block sizes of one megabyte are used also we use zone maps to skip entire
blocks that the data requested is not contained in that block a significant factor in redshift high performance is the use of columnar
storage it's a columnar database which is optimized for scan operations so columnar storage is really different
from row storage which is what traditional relational databases use instead of locating data in rows in the same location on a disk
redshift keeps columns column data physically adjacent so when performing an aggregation on hundreds of million rows in a single
query such as calculating the average age of everyone in a database for example rush is able to return the results
really really quickly
one of the features that a lot of the customers i work with are really excited about with redshift is point and click resize any of us who have worked with
data warehouses will know that the resize experience can be well sometimes a several week or several month program process once you get that
hardware to resize your data warehouse with redshift the resize experience is really easy and really fast
planning preparation as i said often takes weeks when it's time to execute but with redshift you can scale up and scale down in a single click
by selecting the resize button on the management console aws management console the user is prompted to enter
the new desired cluster details basically the instance type and the number of nodes you're required and that's it your cluster goes into
read-only mode well while the cluster resizes and importantly the cluster stays online so you can
resize a petabyte size data warehouse while remaining online and read-only mode entirely the way this works is that
a new target is provisioned in the background and you're only charged for the source cluster while this is all happening
it's fully automated so data is automatically redistributed to the new nodes after you resize as i mentioned it goes into
read-only mode during resize and all of the data copying actually happens parallel node to node so it doesn't have to go through the leader
node basically what that means is that resize is a lot faster it's more efficient and uh you're not charged for anything that you're not
using once the resize is complete we do a quick dns flip over and that way your customers have no
downtime and your end applications can have a fully resized cluster to use
immediately importantly amazon redshift has security
built in you can encrypt your date your source data in s3 using either server-side encryption or your own
encryption keys when you transmit that data to reshift in parallel using the copy command all of that data can be secured using
ssl in transit and most importantly when your data is at rest in redshift we use hardware accelerated aes 256-bit
encryption to encrypt every piece of data in redshift so all blocks on disk in in redshift and on amazon s3 can be
encrypted end-to-end from at rest and transit to process also there's no direct access to compute
nodes so you can shield uh you can shield your data from any rogue operators that
that may happen in a security event and lastly it supports amazon vpc and recently we also announced support
for resource level controls so you can control very specifically what iam users what sub users and groups
have access to reshift resources on aws
a big part of security is also there's data security there's encryption but there's also backup and dr and how do
you recover uh you know if you if your data gets corrupted or something happens and you need to get back to a previous state
what's great about reshift is we're constantly replicating the replication within the cluster and s3 is happening all the time
so backup sets three are continuous automatic and incremental they're designed an s3 as a service that
we're backing up to has eleven nines of durability so it's continuous and automatic and incremental to a service that has eleven
nines of durability we continuously monitor and uh the the cluster so for example if you were
running a data warehouse yourself and and a node or a drive failed uh you would have to replace that and
potentially take your cluster offline with redshift all of this is transparent we automatically replace um cluster nodes and fail drives
transparently in the background and stream the data back from s3 as
as the cluster recovers and we add new nodes to replace the failed capacity
there's one more point to make about the current state of data analysis and this is i think where redshift is really a game changer various
analysts have attempted to quantify the gap between data generated by applications and data that makes its way into an analytical environment
the general trend is that the gap is large and growing in the people simply can't capture and process the volume of
data they're generating so redshift is specifically designed to eliminate two of the major barriers to broad adoptions of analytics
effort and cost operational data often does not find its way to the data warehouse or any kind of analytical
environment because the cost of a data warehouse prevents smaller less proven data sets from getting entry
on top of this the effort required to bring data into the warehouse is substantial relative to its perceived value so redshift has been
built and priced to change this it's allowing customers to close the gap and start analyzing all of their data
redshift was built with a focus on performance price and ease of use the xl nodes provide two terabytes of
storage and cost less than one dollar an hour to get started if you need more than a single node the
single node price is simply multiplied by the number of nodes you provision so there's linear pricing you only need to remember one price you
can also reserve instances for one or three years and save over forty percent off the on-demand price for a
one-year reservation and over seventy percent with a three-year reservation reserved instances apply
all of this translates to less than one thousand dollars per terabyte to keep all your data online for a full
year right shift as a service integrates with multiple data services so it does not
stand alone it's as you saw in the beginning we have a rich a broad and deep ecosystem of services that we provide as part of the
amazon web services platform it has direct i mentioned parallel copy command from s3 and also from dynamodb
you can also integrate it with other services running on our cloud computing platform ec2
emr and redshift are often complementary a lot of people are doing for example etl work on a mapreduce cluster
and then pushing that data into redshift via s3 i mentioned s3 a lot it's a simple
storage service with 11 9's of durability a great place to not only backup your data but also to stage your data
for example between an etl process and a load commander to reshift or for long-term backups before you you
possibly migrate that data to glacier for long-term storage lastly all of our services are are
designed to work in a hybrid environment as well if you have some or all of your data or some applications running on a corporate
data center you can use services such as direct connect and aws storage gateway to migrate that data or to leverage that
data in a cloud environment like aws in redshift accelerated
transfers through storage gateway to s3 for example or direct connect to provide a bridge between your
on-premises applications and your data warehouse hosted in the cloud on aws so i hope that was a useful overview
of aws and redshift and i with that i'd like to pass it on to our partner dices
